title: Atilio Stampone
text:
Atilio Stampone (born 1 July 1926) is an Argentine pianist, composer and arranger prominent in the <a href="Tango%20%28music%29">Tango</a> genre.
Life and work.
He was born to Romana Zangone, from <a href="Calabria">Calabria</a>, and Antonio Stampone, a <a href="pasta">pasta</a> maker from <a href="Napoli">Napoli</a>, in the middle-class <a href="San%20Crist%C3%B3bal%2C%20Buenos%20Aires">San Cristóbal</a> section of <a href="Buenos%20Aires">Buenos Aires</a>. His older brother, Giuseppe, was by then, at age 14, a <a href="bandone%C3%B3n">bandoneón</a>ist in an <a href="orquesta%20t%C3%ADpica">orquesta típica</a>, and when the young Atilio underwent surgery for an acute <a href="appendicitis">appendicitis</a> at age 10, Giuseppe bought his convalescing younger brother a <a href="piano">piano</a>. Shortly afterwards, Atilio Stampone joined his elder brother's tango ensemble.
Stampone joined bandleader Roberto Dimas in his Café Marzotto orchestra, a popular <a href="Corrientes%20Avenue">Corrientes Avenue</a> act, in 1941, and <a href="Pedro%20Maffia">Pedro Maffia</a>'s Tibidabo <a href="cabaret">cabaret</a> orchestra in 1942; impressed with his ability, Maffia personally sought permission for the young pianist's appearance in the risqué setting from his father, who agreed on condition that ""you, Pedrito, personally see him to the <a href="tram">tram</a> for home as soon the show is over. Atilio is a good kid, and I don't want him living in a cabaret;"" with that agreement, he divided his time between the orchestra and his studies at the <a href="Colegio%20Nacional%20de%20Buenos%20Aires">Colegio Nacional de Buenos Aires</a>, a prestigious public <a href="college%20preparatory%20school">college preparatory school</a>. He later worked with Roberto Rufino and Alberto Cámara, and in 1945, met bandoneónist and avant-garde composer <a href="%C3%81stor%20Piazzolla">Ástor Piazzolla</a>.
He joined Piazzolla in 1946, and following the group's dissolution in 1948, Stampone became a pupil of <a href="Vincenzo%20Scaramuzza">Vincenzo Scaramuzza</a>, who helped perfect his technical skill as a pianist. Bandleader <a href="Mariano%20Mores">Mariano Mores</a> hired Stampone as a soloist in two, 1949 <a href="musical%20comedy">musical comedy</a> productions, "El otro yo de Marcela" and "Bésame Petronita", and following these shows, he joined bandleader <a href="Juan%20Carlos%20Cobi%C3%A1n">Juan Carlos Cobián</a>. 
Stampone earned a presidential scholarship from <a href="Juan%20Per%C3%B3n">Juan Perón</a> in 1950, by which he studied under maestro Carlos Zecchi at the <a href="Conservatorio%20di%20Santa%20Cecilia">Conservatorio di Santa Cecilia</a>, in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>. Touring <a href="France">France</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, and the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a>, Stampone returned to Buenos Aires in 1952 and formed an orchestra with bandoneónist <a href="Leopoldo%20Federico">Leopoldo Federico</a>. The Stampone-Federico Orchestra recorded for the <a href="TK%20Records">TK</a> label, notably on compositions such as "Criolla linda" ("Pretty Country Girl") and "Tierrita" ("Small Land"). Federico's contract with ratings leader <a href="Radio%20Belgrano">Radio Belgrano</a> in 1955 left Stampone with sole control of the orchestra, which popularized "El Marne" (<a href="Eduardo%20Arolas">Eduardo Arolas</a>), "Nueve puntos" (<a href="Francisco%20Canaro">Francisco Canaro</a>), "Confesión" (<a href="Enrique%20Santos%20Disc%C3%A9polo">Enrique Santos Discépolo</a> and <a href="Luis%20C%C3%A9sar%20Amadori">Luis César Amadori</a>), Stampone's own "Afiches" ("Posters," lyrics by <a href="Homero%20Exp%C3%B3sito">Homero Expósito</a>), and numerous other standards; "Afiches" helped popularize one of the premier tango vocalists, <a href="Roberto%20Goyeneche">Roberto Goyeneche</a>. 
He continued to collaborate with other groups, including Piazzolla's <a href="Octeto%20Buenos%20Aires">Octeto Buenos Aires</a>. Their 1957 album, "Tango progresivo", became notorious for its poor <a href="audio%20engineering">sound editing</a>, however, and was pulled from store shelves (making copies of the record a collectible, later on). Stampone recorded "Tango Argentino" for <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> label <a href="Audio%20Fidelity%20Records">Audio Fidelity Records</a> in 1958, an album known for "El <a href="Estaci%C3%B3n%20Once">once</a>" (<a href="Osvaldo%20Fresedo">Osvaldo Fresedo</a>), "La rayuela" ("Hopscoth," <a href="Julio%20de%20Caro">Julio de Caro</a>), "Cabulero" ("Gambler," by <a href="Leopoldo%20Federico">Leopoldo Federico</a>), and "Sensiblero" (Julián Plaza). He married the former Lucía Marcó in 1958, and they had two children.
Stampone joined the Microfón label in 1959, where he recorded a double record, with two instrumentals and two with Ricardo Ruiz on vocals. He continued to work with this record company in subsequent decades, and recorded over ten albums for Microfón with his tango revivalist orchestra, some of whose notable members have been: Eduardo Walczak and Tito Besprovan (<a href="violin">violin</a>s), Abraham Selenson (<a href="viola">viola</a>), Enrique Lanoo and <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Bragato">José Bragato</a> (<a href="cello">cello</a>), Osvaldo Montes (<a href="bandone%C3%B3n">bandoneón</a>), Rubén Ruiz (<a href="guitar">guitar</a>), Omar Murtagh (<a href="double%20bass">double bass</a>), and <a href="Eladia%20Bl%C3%A1zquez">Eladia Blázquez</a> and <a href="Virginia%20Luque">Virginia Luque</a> (vocals).
Stampone also became known for his performances at the <a href="Palais%20de%20Glace">Palais de Glace</a> (Buenos Aires), and for a number of film score compositions, including those for <a href="period%20piece">period piece</a> director <a href="Leopoldo%20Torre%20Nilsson">Leopoldo Torre Nilsson</a>'s "<a href="Un%20Guapo%20del%20900%20%281960%20film%29">Un Guapo del 900</a>" ("A Cad out of 1900", 1960), and "La mano en la trampa" ("<a href="The%20Hand%20in%20the%20Trap">The Hand in the Trap</a>", 1961).
He joined two partners, <a href="Football%20in%20Argentina">football</a> <a href="striker%20%28football%29">striker</a> <a href="Rinaldo%20Martino">Rinaldo Martino</a> and actor Pedro Aleandro, in establishing "Caño 14," in 1964. The downtown Buenos Aires tango hall became among the best-known venues of its type, and helped maintain the genre's following during its pre-revival era in the 1960s and '70s, attracting the most important names in local tango at the time, including Troilo, pianist <a href="Horacio%20Salg%C3%A1n">Horacio Salgán</a>, bandoneónist <a href="Ubaldo%20de%20L%C3%ADo">Ubaldo de Lío</a>, <a href="Tango%20%28dance%29">dancer</a> <a href="Juan%20Carlos%20Copes">Juan Carlos Copes</a>, and many others; one featured performer, <a href="w%3Aes%3AEnrique%20Mario%20Francini">Enrique Mario Francini</a>, died on its stage clutching his violin. 
His 1970 album, "Concepto", marked a radical change in Stampone's revivalist style, incorporating a <a href="choir">choir</a> and instilling the music with a more symphonic sound; among its notable pieces are "Responso" (<a href="An%C3%ADbal%20Troilo">Aníbal Troilo</a>) and "Orgullo criollo" ("<a href="Criollo%20people">Criollo</a> Pride," by <a href="Julio%20de%20Caro">Julio de Caro</a> and <a href="Pedro%20Laurenz">Pedro Laurenz</a>). Some of his own compositions popularized by the orchestra were "Con pan y cebolla" ("Bread and Onions"), "De Homero a Homero" ("From <a href="Homer">Homer</a> to <a href="Homero%20Exp%C3%B3sito">Homer</a>"), "Desencanto" ("Heartbreak"), "Aguatero" ("Water Vendor"), "<a href="Enrique%20Cad%C3%ADcamo">Cadícamo</a>", "Ciudadano" ("Citizen"), "Concertango", "El Niño", "El <a href="Tapir">Tapir</a>", "Fiesta de mi ciudad" ("Celebrating My City"), "Fiesta y <a href="Milonga%20%28music%29">milonga</a>", "Impar" ("Odd Number"), "Mi amigo Cholo", "Mocosa" ("Spoiled Girl"), "Taconeando" ("Stomping"), "Pequeña" ("Girl"), and "Vida mía" ("My Life"), among others.
Stampone composed the score for the Oscar Araiz's <a href="ballet">ballet</a> "Tango" in 1981, and in 1984, composed incidental music for director <a href="Luis%20Puenzo">Luis Puenzo</a>'s "<a href="The%20Official%20Story">The Official Story</a>" (winner of the 1986 <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Foreign%20Language%20Film">Best Foreign Language Film</a> Oscar). His 1987 production, "Tango en concierto", debuted at <a href="Madrid">Madrid</a>'s <a href="Teatro%20Real">Teatro Real</a>, and was a success in both <a href="Spain">Spain</a> and <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>. Other compositions from that era include the score for <a href="Marcos%20Zurinaga">Marcos Zurinaga</a>'s "<a href="Tango%20Bar">Tango Bar</a>" (1987, starring <a href="Ra%C3%BAl%20Juli%C3%A1">Raúl Juliá</a>) and "Discepolín" (1989, a theatre production honoring Tango composer <a href="Enrique%20Santos%20Disc%C3%A9polo">Enrique Santos Discépolo</a>). His renown, as well as his activism on behalf of <a href="intellectual%20property%20right">intellectual property right</a>s, earned the election by his peers as President of <a href="SADAIC">SADAIC</a>, the Argentine Society of Composers, in 1985.
Caño 14, the storied tango hall, closed in 1987. It reopened ten years later, however, relocating to 2134 Vicente López Street (in the <a href="Recoleta%2C%20Buenos%20Aires">Recoleta</a> section of Buenos Aires). Stampone retired as President of SADAIC, succeeded by <a href="Ariel%20Ram%C3%ADrez">Ariel Ramírez</a>, in 1993; but remained in its board of directors. He presided over <a href="Konex%20Award">Konex Award</a> juries in 1985 and 2005, and in 2000, was named Music Director of the <a href="Juan%20de%20Dios%20Filiberto%20National%20Orchestra%20of%20Argentine%20Music">Juan de Dios Filiberto National Orchestra of Argentine Music</a>. He was later named director of the City Orchestra of Buenos Aires, while continuing his duties at the Filiberto Orchestra, and was featured in his role as conductor in Miguel Kohan and <a href="Gustavo%20Santaolalla">Gustavo Santaolalla</a>'s 2008 ode to aging Tango greats, "<a href="Caf%C3%A9%20de%20los%20maestros">Café de los maestros</a>".
